MainClaim.text: "Spenser's recovery of place in The Faerie Queene

sCourtesie.text: "Calidore's virtue is defined on the basis of three discontinuous moments: the pitfalls of immediate experience

sTrial.text: "The trial of Mirabella establishes the low point in the history of courtesy

sAbduction.text: "The abduction of Serena by cannibals leads to a basic conflict in interpretations

sVision.text: "Calidore's vision on Mount Acidale reveals his indebtedness to traditional iconography and the tension between ideals and their fulfillment."

sHumanism.text: "Spenser's originality as a Renaissance poet is linked to his use of literary procedures that express but also complicate his relationship to traditional humanism."

sIdealism.text: "Calidore's idealism derives from an ideal court

sSubjectivity.text: "Calidore's actions as a Renaissance courtier never leave the world of experience entirely behind

sPhenomenology.text: "Spenser's use of phenomenology in The Faerie Queene

sRecoveryOfPlace.text: "The recovery of place involves a slow spiritual awakening that embraces the lowest levels of erotic awareness as well as the highest reaches of 'ideal' experience."

sReconciliation.text: "Calidore's reconciliation of ideal and real is a sublime metaphor whose deeper meaning is corroborated by tradition and phenomenology alike."

PhenomenologyInSpenser.text: "Spenser's use of phenomenology in The Faerie Queene

sSubjectivityIsNotTheNarrativeCenter.text: "Calidore himself is not the narrative 'center' of Courtesy

sVisionIsNotAPoliticalMission.text: "Calidore's chivalrous mission may have led him to discover an actual Gloriana

sReturnToPastoral.text: "Calidore's return to pastoral culminates in the overcoming of nature as an external obstacle and prepares him for a future life of concrete acts and the company of historical persons."

sIdealismDerivesFromAnIdealCourt.text: "Calidore's idealism derives from an ideal court

sIdealismRequiresPoeticVision.text: "Calidore's idealism requires a poetic vision of the supernatural for its fulfillment

sSubjectivityRequiresNoesisAndNoema.text: "Calidore's reconciliation of ideal and real must be understood in terms of the phenomenological difference between noesis and noema."

sVisionIsAMetaphor.text: "Calidore's vision on Mount Acidale is a metaphor that reveals the tension between ideals and their fulfillment."

sReturnToPastoralIsSublime.text: "Calidore's return to pastoral is a sublime metaphor whose deeper meaning is corroborated by tradition and phenomenology alike."

sIdealismIsNotAPoliticalMission.text: "Calidore's idealism is not a political mission

sSubjectivityIsNotAPoliticalMission.text: "Calidore's subjectivity is not a political mission

sIdealismRequiresPoeticVisionOfSupernatu.text: "Calidore's idealism requires a poetic vision of the supernatural for its fulfillment."

sSubjectivityRequiresPhenomenologicalDif.text: "Calidore's reconciliation of ideal and real must be understood in terms of the phenomenological difference between noesis and noema."

PhenomenologyInSpenserIsEspeciallySuitab.text: "Spenser's use of phenomenology in The Faerie Queene

PhenomenologyInSpenserAllowsForSubjectiv.text: "Spenser's use of phenomenology in The Faerie Queene
